children.subject: Oops - you are right. 17.5 for phase 2...pardon the typo.

Why is phase 2 this semester limited to 17 units? Wasn't it 17.5 last semester. This does not make any sense. Because phase 1 was 13.5 units (so I can take PE) and then I will have to drop that to take the classes I want (usually 4 units).

Since EE16B is set up to all time conflicts, you will be allowed to move up the waitlist.

That said, remember it is YOUR responsibility to check and make sure faculty allows time conflict for the class. Just because the system allows it doesn't mean that the instructors allow it. Faculty are under NO obligation to accommodate conflicting exam times.
If I am waitlisted for EE16B, and I have another class at the same time as EE16B lecture, will I be allowed to move up the waitlist?

I can only tell you CS70 is set to allow the time conflict. I recommend that you re-read the error message and make sure it is actually the time conflict that is preventing enrollment. Do you meet the enrollment requirements? Do you have enough units to enroll without exceeding 13.5 units? Do you have a hold on your account?

Resolved, appreciate the response.

I am not sure if this is intended, but this is the issue I ran into:

With CS70 in my schedule, I cannot add the humanities course due to schedule conflict.

However, with the humanities course in my schedule, I can successfully add CS70 to my schedule.
I tried to enroll for a humanities class at the same time as CS70 lecture, but CalCentral is not allowing me to. Is this intended?

Hmm - I can see your confusion. Here's how the system works:

We prioritize who can get into classes by using reserve caps. If you meet the requirements of the reserve cap and there is space, you will be allowed into the class. If all reserved seats are full, you will be placed on the wait list even if you meet the requirements.

The system does, in fact, automatically process the wait list in sequential order and enrolls anyone who doesn't have some sort of 'error' blocking their enrollment. ('Errors' could be: not enough available units, not meeting reserve cap requirements, no open seats in the reserve group for which you qualify, or in past semesters time conflicts.) If more seats become available in the reserve cap, then people who meet that requirement will be enrolled - still based on their position on the wait list.

While the current language on the Getting into Upper Div Classes post is TECHNICALLY correct, I understand it doesn't seem that way to students - while it is reserve caps doing the prioritization, it looks like the wait list is doing it. 

The KEY MESSAGE to take away is that when the reserve caps come down near or at the end of phase 2, then no priority is given to the majors.

I'm a little confused since this post seems to contradict the "Getting in to Upper Div Classes" post, which states that "Wait lists are automatically processed in numerical order based on the waitlist position. A student’s major is NOT taken into consideration when the wait list is processed." Is this the case, or are students' majors taken into account when processing the waitlist during Phases 1 and 2?
CS 194-26 is TTH, and I am trying to take a class that has conflict only on Thursday. Is there anyway I could do that?

"Time Conflicts - NEW for F18: The enrollment system WILL ALLOW time conflicts between CompSci classes and other classes. However, even though CalCentral will allow enrollment into both classes, it is still the student’s responsibility to plan their schedule carefully. Departments and faculty are NOT required or expected to accommodate students’ schedule conflicts, and the Instructor of Record may decline to enroll or Instructor Drop a student from a class if they cannot be present for all schedule activities, including midterms and finals. 

Best practice is to speak to the instructors before enrolling in time conflicted classes."

CS 61B was expanded by 105 seats last night-- I was #76 on the waitlist but still didn't get into the class. Is there any other factor considered in enrollment? My friend formerly at #93 got in and I'm not sure why I was bypassed. Enrolling would not hit any unit caps.

history.content:
How does the enrollment system process the wait list?

 

Once enrollment opens, Campus Solutions (the enrollment system) processes wait lists four times daily at 6:30am, 12:30pm, 6:30pm, and 12:30am.

During Phases 1 and 2: The wait list is processed in sequential order according to reserve caps associated with each course. Students who are further down the wait list and meet the reserve cap requirements will be enrolled (assuming there is space in the sections) before students higher on the wait list who do NOT meet the reserve cap requirements.

During the Adjustment period: The wait list is processed in sequential order – no preference is given to EECS or CS majors because reserve caps have come down.

 

     Example: CS 188 has 13 open seats and a wait list

     Joe, an undeclared L&S student holds position 12 on the wait list.

     Tina, a declared EECS major holds position 20 on the wait list.

     During Phases 1 & 2, Tina will be enrolled and Joe will remain on the wait list because he doesn’t meet the reserve cap requirements.

     During Adjustment period: Joe is enrolled into the class and Tina remains on the wait lilst because the wait list is processed in sequential order. Since reserve caps are no longer active, no priority is given to EECS majors.

 

Caution: Although time conflicts will no longer prevent students from enrolling into EECS classes, other problems WILL. If you are wait listed for a class and see open seats or are not moving up the wait list, check the following:

  •         Make sure you have enough units available to enroll into the class without exceeding the upper unit limit for the phase.  (Phase 1 = 13.5, Phase 2 = 17.5, and Adjustment Period = 20.5)
  •         Check CalCentral to see if you have a hold on your account. You may need to speak with an adviser and/or the Registrar to remove the hold.
